bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses the Kissinger interview, which was published in a Cleveland newspaper. He offers his opinion on the role played by Kissinger during the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 11, 1941
div1.p:
I enjoyed so much receiving your last letter. First of all, I am delighted
to hear that you are again feeling fit after your unhappy experience in the hospital.

Thank you so much for your kind words about my Cleveland talk. The audience
seemed to appreciate fully the significance of the story. It was a great pleasure
for me to meet Mrs. Reed, Colonel Siler and again General Ireland and his wife. The
Wyeth folks sent me several clippings from newspapers, including the one from the
Plain Dealer of June 3. That interview certainly was a mess but I do not believe
we can blame Kissinger. I happened to be standing at the door of the room where
the reporter was interviewing Kissinger. The interview was very brief, but some-
body gave the reporter a copy of my talk. You will note that much of the supposed
interview with Kissinger consists of fragments of sentences from my talk. The
man would use a half sentence or a whole sentence, filling out the rest himself,
and he certainly got it all bawled up. Since Kissinger had not seen my talk pre-
viously, we must conclude that the reporter made up the story with the grossest
carelessness. That small erroneous part which may (or may not) have derived from
Kissinger, unfortunately we will have to forgive.

While chatting with me he told me that not long ago he had some sort of
an affair which affected his face but which cleared up. The thought passed through
my head that he might have had a slight stroke. Mr. Kissinger was called upon to
make just the briefest acknowledgement of an introduction. His speech was only
about three or four sentences long but he was even more ill at case than usual.
As he said, he was “all choked up” and had to stop a moment to regain his composure.
That was Monday afternoon. He went home the next day, I think, arriving Tuesday
evening, very happy about the whole affair. Wednesday morning at nine o'clock he
had a very severe stoke and two days later when Mrs. Kissinger wrote me he was still
unconscious and not expected to live. I have been trying to keep in touch with them
but have heard nothing yet. So, if the poor fellow gave any erroneous statements to
the report, we will have to excuse it on the basis of his confusion.

I am aware that several of those closely connected with the yellow fever
affair (not including yourself) have on occasion spoken a little slightingly to me
of Kissinger, accusing him of having “gone into the hero business” a little too ex-
tensively, but I have seen the fellow in his own home and also here in Rochester
and elsewhere, and I am absolutely sure that he deserves to be forgiven if one
analyzes his personality and career. I entirely agree with you that his myclitis
had nothing whatever to do with his yellow fever but who can blame him, when he was
down and out, with his wife taking in washings, etc., for jumping at the chance to
get help from Dr. Peabody and others on the strength of his previous heroism. If
that made a hero out of him it has meant bread and butter, and taking his wife from
the wash tub. Certainly I must look on his actions with considerable charity. His
actions are explained further by an analysis of his simple character. He is nothing
but a rather ignorant farmer who more or less mentally died after his Cuban exper-
iences. Life has meant nothing since then except in retrospect. Living on a little,

rather isolated farm, the only excitement that has come to his life has been the
occasional invitation to go out and speak on the yellow fever story. Not having
had enough education to write the story up, he has relied on his memory which has
become rather poor. He has little sense of the relative values as I saw in his
home, when he showed me with a simple, childish delight the citation making him an
honorary member of some senior high school class. This citation pleased him
practically as much as the Congressional Medal of Honor, and his honorary membership
in both Kiwanis and Rotary were as impressive to him as a congressional citation.
I would say that in the last analysis he was a simple but brave soldier and a
Christian gentleman who deserves understanding rather than condemnation.

Naturally, he would like to connect his myclitis with his yellow fever.
That would make it easier to bear and one's friends are always inclined to do such
things. For example, on several recent occasions when some senator or congressman
died, his friends in Washington promptly have stated that “he died on the battlefield
fighting for the rights of the people, etc.”

I for one will entirely agree that you are completely exonerated from any
responsibility for getting yourself in the Wyeth painting. Your friends are entirely
responsible and are very happily responsible. It was felt, and justly so, that you
and General Wood had done so much for the Board that you deserved inclusion and I am
delighted that you are in it.

I am overwhelmed with your offer to give me the Walter Reed contract. I
cannot tell you how greatly I would appreciate this, But before making your final
decision I wonder if you honestly think I should be the custodian of it. How about
your own son's interest in it? Should you still insist on giving it to me, I can
only tell you how very grateful I am for it and I shall promise that it will be safe-
guarded as it should be and made an integral part of the collection of Reediana which
I am assembling. I may have told you of the great kindness of Dr. Kelly who handed
over to me all his collection of Reed material, including many letters of Carroll,
Agramonte and a couple of Reed. All of this material will be carefully preserved and
presented permanently to the Mayo Clinic on the condition that it be accessible to
all those interested in it, and it is my hope to have much of the material actually
copied in photostatic form and deposited in the four or five institutions who have
so far expressed an interest in my collection. For sentimental reasons I should be
very glad, should you decide to send it to me, to have the contract in its original
frame. The story you told me about its disappearance, etc. is certainly an interesting
one and I would just as soon have it in that form. May I suggest that I believe if you
should phone to the American Railway Express Company, they would call for the picture,
pack it appropriately and ship it to me, without any bother to you. I should be only
too delighted to defray the expenses entailed.

May I say that Mrs. Franck's work and charge were entirely satisfactory.
I know she worked very hard on it and the information is worth much more than her bill.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. psh:ds
